{{Infobox SCOTUS case |Litigants=Ex parte Crow Dog |ArgueDate=November 26 |ArgueYear=1883 |DecideDate=December 17 |DecideYear=1883 |FullName=Ex parte Kan-gi-shun-ca (otherwise known as Crow Dog) |USVol=109 |USPage=556 |Citation=3 S. Ct. 396; 27 L. Ed. 1030 |Prior=U.S. v. Kan-gi-shun-ca, 14 N.W. 437, 3 Dakota 106 (Dakota Terr. 1882) |Subsequent= |Holding=Held that a federal court did not have jurisdiction to try an Indian who killed another Indian on the reservation when the offense had been tried by the tribal court, writ of ''habeas corpus'' granted. |SCOTUS=1882-1887 |Majority=Matthews |JoinMajority=''unanimous'' |Concurrence= |JoinConcurrence= |Concurrence2= |JoinConcurrence2= |Concurrence/Dissent= |JoinConcurrence/Dissent= |Dissent= |JoinDissent= |Dissent2= |JoinDissent2= |LawsApplied=Revised Stat. §2146 (1878) }} '''''Ex parte Crow Dog''''', {{ussc|109|556|1883}}, is a decision of the [[Supreme Court of the United States]] that followed the death of one member of a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] tribe at the hands of another on [[Indian reservation|reservation]] land.{{refn|The phrase ''[[ex parte]]'', meaning for or by one side only, has traditionally been used in the captions of petitions for the [[writ]] of ''[[habeas corpus]]'', which were (and in some jurisdictions, still are) styled as "''Ex parte'' Doe", where [[John Doe|Doe]] was the name of the petitioner who was alleged to be wrongfully held. As the Supreme Court's description of nineteenth century practice in ''[[Ex parte Milligan]]'' shows, however, such proceedings were not ''ex parte'' in any significant sense. The prisoner's ''ex parte'' application sought only an order requiring the person holding the prisoner to appear before the court to justify the prisoner's detention; no order requiring the freeing of a prisoner could be given until after the jailer was given the opportunity to contest the prisoner's claims at a hearing on the merits.|group=fn}} [[Crow Dog]] was a member of the [[Brulé]] band of the [[Lakota people|Lakota]] Sioux. On August 5, 1881 he shot and killed [[Spotted Tail]], a Lakota chief; there are different accounts of the background to the killing. The tribal council dealt with the incident according to [[Sioux]] tradition, and Crow Dog paid restitution to the dead man's family. However, the U.S. authorities then prosecuted Crow Dog for [[murder]] in a federal court. He was found guilty and sentenced to hang. The Supreme Court held that unless authorized by [[United States Congress|Congress]], federal courts had no jurisdiction to try cases where the offense had already been tried by the tribal council.''Ex parte Crow Dog'', {{ussc|109|556|1883}}. Crow Dog was therefore released. This case was the first time in history that an Indian was held on trial for the murder of another Indian. The case led to the [[Major Crimes Act]] in 1885, which placed some major crimes (initially seven, now 15) under federal jurisdiction if committed by an Indian against another Indian on a reservation or tribal land. This case was the beginning of the [[plenary power]] legal doctrine that has been used in Indian case law to limit [[Tribal sovereignty in the United States|tribal sovereignty]]. ==Background== [[File:Siouxreservationmap.png|thumb|left|200px|alt=map of Great Sioux Reservation|Great Sioux Reservation]] ===Treaties and statutes=== Crow Dog{{refn|Crow Dog's [[Lakota people|Lakota]] name was Kangi Sunká.{{smallcaps|Sidney L. Harring}}, {{smallcaps|Crow Dog's Case: American Indian Sovereignty, Tribal Law, and United States Law in the Nineteenth Century}} 3 (1994).|group="fn"}} was a [[Brulé]]{{refn|The Brulé were a band of the Lakota (also called Teton) Sioux. The Lakota name for the band is Sičháŋǧu Oyáte.{{smallcaps|Donovin Arleigh Sprague}}, {{smallcaps|Rosebud Sioux}} 7 (2005).|group="fn"}} subchief who lived on the [[Great Sioux Reservation]], in the part that is now the [[Rosebud Indian Reservation]] in south-central [[South Dakota]] on its border with [[Nebraska]]. The tribe had made several treaties with the [[United States]], the most significant being the 1868 [[Treaty of Fort Laramie (1868)|Treaty of Fort Laramie]].[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/Vol2/treaties/sio0998.htm 2 {{smallcaps|Indian Affairs: Laws and Treaties}}] 998 (Charles J. Kappler, ed.,1904). This treaty provided that Indians agreed to turn over those accused of crimes to the [[Indian agent]], a representative of the U.S. government in Indian affairs.{{refn|The actual treaty language is: "If bad men among the Indians shall commit a wrong or depredation upon the person or property of any one, white, black, or Indians, subject to the authority of the United States, and at peace therewith, the Indians herein named solemnly agree that they will, upon proof made to their agent and notice by him, deliver up the wrong-doer to the United States..."Kappler, at 998. This was common language between 1821 and 1868 in treaties with Indian tribes.|group="fn"}} The treaty also stipulated that tribal members would stay on the reservation provided (which included the [[Black Hills]]){{refn|The name of the Black Hills in the Lakota language is Pahá Sápa.{{smallcaps|Over 5,000 Terms and Expressions from Aarigaa! to Zopilote}} 263-64 (Wil Blevins, ed., 2002).|group="fn"}} unless three-fourths of the adult male tribal members agreed otherwise.Kappler, at 1002. In 1874, Colonel [[George Armstrong Custer]] led a party into the Black Hills to investigate rumors of gold. Once he announced the discovery of gold on [[French Creek (Cheyenne River)|French Creek]], the [[Black Hills Gold Rush]] brought prospectors into that area in violation of the Fort Laramie treaty.See [https://www.ourdocuments.gov/doc.php?flash=true&doc=42''Treaty of Fort Laramie with Sioux, etc.''], 1851. The Lakota protested in 1875 to no avail, as the United States demanded that the Lakota sell the Black Hills.{{smallcaps|Edward Lazarus}}, {{smallcaps|Black Hills/White Justice: The Sioux Nation versus the United States, 1775 to the Present}} 79-80 (1999). The United States then declared the Lakota as hostile, which started the [[Great Sioux War of 1876|Black Hills War]].Lazarus, at 84. The war included the [[Battle of the Rosebud]], the [[Battle of the Little Bighorn]] and the [[Battle of Slim Buttes]], among others. The war ended in 1877. Crow Dog fought in this war, while the man he later killed, [[Spotted Tail]], did not.{{smallcaps|Peter F. Panzeri, Little Big Horn 1876: Custer's Last Stand}} 25 (1995). Congress passed a law later in 1877 ({{usstat|19|176}}) that took the Black Hills away from the tribe, contrary to the language of the treaty.[http://digital.library.okstate.edu/kappler/Vol1/HTML_files/SES0166.html {{smallcaps|1 Indian Affairs: Laws and Treaties}}] 166 (Charles J. Kappler, ed., 1904). ===Murder of Spotted Tail=== [[File:CrowDog&Horse1898.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=photograph of Chief Crow Dog|The shooter, Chief Crow Dog (Kangi Sunká)]] On August 5, 1881 Crow Dog shot and killed Spotted Tail,{{refn|Spotted Tail's Lakota name was Siŋté Glešká.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 282.|group="fn"}} who was the uncle of [[Oglala Lakota]] war leader [[Crazy Horse]].{{smallcaps|George Hyde & Harry H. Anderson}}, {{smallcaps|Spotted Tail's Folk: a History of the Brulé Sioux}} 83 (2d ed. 1976). Spotted Tail had not been selected as a chief by the tribe, but instead had been appointed by General [[George Crook]] in 1876, which hurt him in the view of many of the tribe.{{smallcaps|Charles Alexander Eastman}}, {{smallcaps|Indian Heroes and Great Chieftains}} 40 (1919). He was viewed as an accommodationist and the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs]] (BIA) referred to him as the "great peace chief."Michael A. Powell, ''Crow Dog and the Issue of Tribal Jurisdiction'', {{smallcaps|Law in the Western United States}} 283 (Gordon Morris Bakken, ed., 2000). He also supervised the [[Indian agency police|tribal police]] of about 300 men.Hyde, at 293. In contrast, Crow Dog was a traditionalistPowell, at 283. and although he had been a captain in the tribal police, he was fired by Spotted Tail sometime after a July 4, 1881, confrontation during which Crow Dog pointed a rifle at Spotted Tail.{{smallcaps|Jeffrey Ostler}}, {{smallcaps|The Plains Sioux and U.S. Colonialism from Lewis and Clark to Wounded Knee}} 198-99 (2004). On August 5, tensions further escalated at a tribal meeting where a number of tribal members criticized Spotted Tail for taking Light-in-the-Lodge, the wife of Medicine Bear, a crippled man, into his household as his second wife.{{smcaps|Eastman}}, at 40; {{smcaps|Harring}}, at 108-09; Gaylen L. Box, ''Crow Dog: Tribal Sovereignty & Criminal Jurisdiction In Indian Country'', {{smallcaps|50-May Advocate (Idaho)}} 13 (2007). It was believed that the killing occurred that day as the result of Crow Dog and Spotted Tail meeting, both armed, and mistaking the other man's intentions.{{smallcaps|Ostler}}, at 201. In another version of the story, Crow Dog was appointed by the tribal council to head the tribal police, which undermined the authority of Spotted Tail. Crow Dog discovered that Spotted Tail was taking money from ranchers for "grazing rights" and he denounced him for it, while Spotted Tail defended the practice.{{smcaps|Eastman}}, at 40; {{smallcaps|Hyde}}, at 313-14. A later conflict with the Indian agent forced the tribal police to disband, and Crow Dog lost his position.{{smallcaps|Hyde}}, at 331. This version makes no mention of another man's wife being the reason for the killing, and states that Crow Dog ambushed Spotted Tail to gain power in the tribe.{{smallcaps|Hyde}}, at 334. There is no consensus among historians as to which events happened as described. In either case, the matter was settled within the tribe, following longstanding tribal custom, by Crow Dog making a [[restitution]] payment of $600,{{refn|Some sources state the amount was $50.{{smallcaps|George Washington Kingsbury & George Martin Smith}}, {{smallcaps|2 History of the Dakota Territory}} 1194 (1915).|group="fn"}} eight horses, and one blanket to Spotted Tail's family.{{smallcaps|Kingsbury}}, at 1194; {{smallcaps|George E. Hyde}}, {{smallcaps|A Sioux Chronicle}} 46-66 (1993); {{smallcaps|Laurence French}}, {{smallcaps|Native American Justice}} 135 (2003); {{smallcaps|Vine Deloria, Jr. & Clifford M. Lytle}}, {{smallcaps|The Nations Within: The Past and Future of American Indian Sovereignty}} 4 (1998); {{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 110. ===Trial=== [[File:Spotted Tail.jpg|thumb|right|200px|alt=photograph of Chief Spotted Tail|The victim, Chief Spotted Tail (Siŋté Glešká)]] Following the killing and the settlement under tribal customs, the Indian agent had Crow Dog arrested and taken to Fort Niobrara, Nebraska.{{smallcaps|Deloria}}, at 4; {{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 110-11. Within 20 days, the [[United States Attorney General|U.S. Attorney General]] and the [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] concluded that the Federal Enclave Act of 1854Now codified at {{usc|18|1152}}. as modified by the [[Assimilative Crimes Act]] allowed the territorial death penalty to be applied to Crow Dog.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 113-15. In September 1881, Crow Dog was indicted by a federal [[grand jury]] for [[murder]] and [[manslaughter]] under the laws of the [[Dakota Territory]]. In March 1882 the case was heard by Judge [[Gideon C. Moody]] at the First Judicial District Court of Dakota, located in [[Deadwood, South Dakota|Deadwood]], South Dakota.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 125-28. The court appointed A. J. Plowman to represent Crow Dog,{{smcaps|French}}, at 135; {{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 121. who claimed that he had been punished and made reparations according to the customs of the Brulé Sioux tribe. According to a contemporary news report of the Deadwood Times{{refn|As cited by Kingsbury, without date of publication or further information.{{smallcaps|Kingsbury}}, at 1193.|group="fn"}} it was the first time "in the history of the country, [that] an Indian is held for trial for the murder of another Indian."{{smallcaps|Kingsbury}}, at 1193. The trial was viewed at the time as a sham,{{refn|One potential juror stated that the word of one white man would outweigh the word of a hundred Indians. In addition, the judge did not allow several witnesses for Crow Dog to testify, including his wife, nor was any information on the various treaties with the tribe admitted into evidence.{{smcaps|French}}, at 136.|group="fn"}} and despite testimonies from Indian witnesses stating that Spotted Tail had killed a rival once before,{{refn|It was noted that Spotted Tail had killed [[Big Mouth]], another Brulé member by having two other Indians grab and hold Big Mouth while Spotted Tail shot him.{{smcaps|French}}, at 136.|group="fn"}} that Spotted Tail drew a pistol on Crow Dog, and that Spotted Tail's intention was to kill Crow Dog,{{smallcaps|Richard Irving Dodge}}, {{smallcaps|The Plains of the Great West and their Inhabitants: Being a Description of the Plains, Game, Indians, &c., of the Great North American Desert}} 271 (1877); {{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 122. Crow Dog was convicted and sentenced to be hanged on May 11, 1882.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 125. The prosecution had presented five Indian witnesses{{refn|The witnesses were He Dog, Ring Thunder, High Bear, Chasing Hawk, and Kills On Horseback.Powell, at 283-84|group="fn"}} who stated that Spotted Tail was ambushed, and some witnesses stated he was unarmed. In an unusual move for a death penalty case, Moody released Crow Dog, allowing him to go home pending his appeal to the territorial Supreme Court. Surprising many of the white citizens of the area, Crow Dog returned to court as required. In May 1882, the territorial Supreme Court affirmed the conviction, and the execution was rescheduled for May 11, 1883.''United States v. Crow Dog'', 14 N.W. 437 (Dak. 1882). Crow Dog then petitioned the [[United States Supreme Court]] for a writ of ''[[habeas corpus]]'' and the Supreme Court accepted the case.''Crow Dog'', 109 U.S. at 557; {{smallcaps|Kingsbury}}, at 1195; {{smcaps|French}}, at 136; {{smallcaps|Vine Deloria, Jr. & Clifford M. Lytle}}, {{smallcaps|American Indians, American Justice}} 168-70 (1983); Powell, at 284. ==Opinion of the Court== [[File:Thomas Stanley Matthews - Brady-Handy.jpg|thumb|left|200px|alt=photograph of Justice T. Stanley Matthews|Justice T. Stanley Matthews, author of the unanimous opinion]] Justice [[Stanley Matthews (lawyer)|Stanley Matthews]] delivered the opinion of the unanimous court. Matthews noted that Crow Dog was indicted for murder under a statute prohibiting murder on federal land.{{refn|"Every person who commits murder-- ... or in any other place under the exclusive jurisdiction of the United States; ... shall suffer death."[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=018/llsl018.db&recNum=1110 Act of Mar. 3, 1875, ch. 145] {{usstat|18|1038}}.|group="fn"}}{{usstat|18|1038}}. Matthews then looked at the federal laws dealing with Indians, including a statute that applied the prohibition on murder to Indian reservations{{refn|"...the general laws of the United States as to punishment of crimes committed in any place within the sole and exclusive jurisdiction of the United States, except the District of Columbia, shall extend to Indian country."[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=018/llsl018.db&recNum=446 Act of Mar. 27, 1854, ch. 26] {{usstat|18|374}}.|group="fn"}}{{usstat|18|374}}. and another covering exceptions to prosecution.{{refn|"The preceding section shall not be construed to extend to crimes committed by one Indian against the person or property of another Indian, nor to any Indian committing any offense who has been punished by the local laws of the tribe..."[http://memory.loc.gov/cgi-bin/ampage?collId=llsl&fileName=018/llsl018.db&recNum=446 Act of Feb. 18, 1875, ch. 80] {{usstat|18|374}}.|group="fn"}}{{usstat|18|374}}. The first statute prohibited murder on federal land, the second statute applied the first statute to reservations, and the last had specific exceptions to prosecution. Matthews felt that this last section was the most critical one in the case, with the section stating unequivocally that federal law: "shall not be construed to extend to [crimes committed by one Indian against the person or property of another Indian, nor to] any Indian committing any offense in the Indian country who has been punished by the local law of the tribe"{{usstat|18|374}}. (brackets in original). Matthews rejected the contention of the United States that the 1868 Treaty of Fort Laramie implicitly repealed the exceptions to prosecution. He stated that since the law had not been amended or changed, and since implied repeals are not favored unless the implication is necessary, to allow such a repeal would be to reverse the general policy of the United States. Matthews said that such a repeal required a "clear expression of the intention of Congress," which was not present in the case. In a clear evocation of the principle of tribal sovereignty,Robert N. Clinton, ''There Is No Federal Supremacy Clause For Indian Tribes'' {{smallcaps|34 Ariz. St. L.J.}} 113 (2002). Matthews stated:
"It tries them, not by their peers, nor by the customs of their people, nor the law of their land, but by superiors of a different race, according to the law of a social state of which they have an imperfect conception, and which is opposed to the traditions of their history, to the habits of their lives, to the strongest prejudices of their savage nature; one which measures the red man's revenge by the maxims of the white man's morality."''Crow Dog'', 109 U.S. at 571; {{smallcaps|Deloria}}, at 26.; Kevin K. Washburn, ''Federal Criminal Law and Tribal Self-Determination'' 84 {{smallcaps|N.C.L. Rev.}} 779 (2006).
As a result, the Court concluded, the First Judicial District Court of Dakota was without jurisdiction to hear the case. The writ of ''habeas corpus'' was issued, discharging Crow Dog from federal custody.''Crow Dog'', 109 U.S. at 572; {{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 129. ==Subsequent developments== ===Major Crimes Act of 1885=== Shocked by the Supreme Court's decision and under strong pressure from the BIA,Clinton, at 113. Congress passed the [[Major Crimes Act]] in response.{{refn|The bill's sponsor, Representative Cutcheon expressed "anger" at the release of a "murderer" into society.Susan M. McGoldrick, ''Jurisdiction to Sentence and Convict for Lesser Included Offenses under the Major Crimes Act: A Critical Assessment of the Keeble Legacy'' {{smallcaps|12 Am. Indian L. Rev. 219}} (1984).|group="fn"}}{{smallcaps|Deloria}}, at 4, 29; Powell, at 286. The Major Crimes Act placed seven serious felony offenses (with amendments over the years, now fifteen) under the jurisdiction of the federal government.{{refn|The original list of offenses was: murder, manslaughter, rape, assault with intent to commit murder, arson, burglary and larceny. Later, Congress added kidnapping, maiming, incest, assault with a dangerous weapon, assault with serious bodily injury, assault of a child under 16, child abuse or neglect, robbery, or a felony under 18 USC Ch. 109A (Sexual Abuse). Territorially, it covered "Indian Country", defined as all reservation land, all Indian allotments, and all dependent Indian communities outside of reservations. The crime had to be committed by an Indian for federal jurisdiction to apply.{{usc|18|1151|1153}}|group="fn"}} Those wishing to [[Cultural assimilation of Native Americans|assimilate]] Indians into mainstream white society{{refn|This included eastern liberal reformers, such as the Indian Rights Association.{{smcaps|French}}, at 136.|group="fn"}} wanted to do away with the "heathen" tribal laws and apply white laws to the tribes.{{smcaps|French}}, at 136-37; {{smallcaps|The Oxford guide to United States Supreme Court decisions}} 66 (Kermit L. Hall, ed., 2001). The BIA had also been attempting since 1874 to extend federal jurisdiction over major crimes to reservations, without any success.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 115-16, 134-35. Beginning in 1882, the [[Indian Rights Association]] (IRA) also tried to extend federal jurisdiction, but in a different manner.{{smallcaps|Tribal Criminal Law and Procedure}} 40-50 (Carrie E. Garrow & Sarah Deer, eds., 2004); {{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 134. The IRA believed that the tribes would be better served by a completely separate court system, modeled after U.S. courts and called agency courts. The only appeal would be to the Commissioner of Indian Affairs.Garrow, at 40-50. The BIA opposed that approach, preferring to try only major crimes in the nearest federal court. ''[[Ex parte]] Crow Dog'' provided the BIA a perfect example of why this was needed, along with an incident involving Spotted Tail's son, Spotted Tail, Jr., in which the younger Spotted Tail participated in a fight during which three Brulé were killed.{{refn|Following a dispute over a woman, White Thunder and Spotted Tail, Jr. were involved in a fight. White Thunder was slain along with his father and Song Pumpkin, and Spotted Tail, Jr. was arrested and confined in jail. Spotted Tail, Jr. was the only Indian released from custody as a result of ''Ex parte Crow Dog''.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 133.|group="fn"}}{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 133. The younger Spotted Tail was also confined pending murder charges, and it took a direct order of the [[United States Secretary of the Interior|Secretary of the Interior]] for the local BIA agents to comply with the Supreme Court decision before he was released.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 133; Washburn, at 779. The BIA also implemented regulations in 1883 criminalizing traditional tribal practices such as war dances and polygamy.Box, at 14. Between the BIA's efforts and the IRA efforts, the law was passed in 1885, making seven offenses federal crimes.{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 136-40. Many members of the Indian tribes were bitter with this outcome for decades afterwards. [[Wayne Ducheneaux]], president of the [[National Congress of American Indians]], testified before Congress on the matter in 1968:Robert D. Probasco, ''Indian Tribes, Civil Rights, and Federal Courts'', 7 {{smallcaps|Tex. Wesleyan L. Rev.}} 119 (2001).
"Before all this came about we had our own method of dealing with law-breakers and in settling disputes between members. That all changed when Crow Dog killed Spotted Tail. Of course, our method of dealing with that was Crow Dog should go take care of Spotted Tail's family, and if he didn't do that we'd banish him from the tribe. But that was considered too barbaric, and thought perhaps we should hang him like civilized people do, so they passed the Major Crimes Act that said we don't know how to handle murderers and they were going to show us."Probasco, at 119.
In 2000, [[Larry Echo Hawk]], a [[Pawnee people|Pawnee]] who had been the [[State attorney general|Attorney General]] of [[Idaho]] and was later the [[Bureau of Indian Affairs#Commissioners and Assistant Secretaries|Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs]], noted that: "The Major Crimes Act was designed to give the federal government authority to criminally prosecute seven specific major crimes committed by Indians in Indian Country. It was a direct assault on the sovereign authority of tribal government over tribal members."[[Larry Echo Hawk]], ''Review: Justice for Native Americans Requires Returning to Our Constitutional Origins Vine Deloria, Jr. & David E. Wilkins Tribes, Treaties, and Constitutional Tribulations'', 4 {{smallcaps|Green Bag 2d}} 101 (2000). ===Tribal sovereignty=== ''Crow Dog'' had a tremendous impact on [[Tribal sovereignty in the United States|tribal sovereignty]].{{smallcaps|Harring}}, at 219. The decision recognized two distinct concepts in addition to those related to criminal law. First, Justice Matthews had noted that under ''[[Cherokee Nation v. Georgia]]'', (1831)''[[Cherokee Nation v. Georgia]]'', {{ussc|30|1|1831|Pet.|5}}. the Brulé tribe had a right to its own law in [[Indian country]].Anthony G. Gulig & Sidney L. Harring, ''An Indian cannot get a morsel of pork...": A retrospective on Crow Dog, Lone Wolf, Blackbird, Tribal Sovereignty, Indian Land and writing Indian history'', 38 {{smallcaps|Tulsa L. Rev.}} 87 (2002). Part of this ruling was based on American constitutional tradition – at that time, Indians were not U.S. citizens{{refn|Indians did not become U.S. citizens until 1924, upon passage of the [[Indian Citizenship Act of 1924]][[Indian Citizenship Act of 1924]], Act of Jun. 2, 1924, ch. 233 {{usstat|43|253}}.|group="fn"}} and according to Matthews did not have a "voice in the selection of representatives and the framing of the laws."''Crow Dog'', 109 U.S. at 569; Clinton, at 113. The case held that Indian tribes retain sovereignty, and is still valid law. For example, ''[[United States v. Lara]]'', (2004)''[[United States v. Lara]]'', {{ussc|541|193|2004}}. cited ''Crow Dog'' when holding that both a tribe and the federal government could prosecute Lara, as they were separate sovereigns. Subsequent cases have supported the concept "that tribal Indians living in Indian country are citizens of the United States first (under the [[plenary power]] doctrine), the tribes second, and the states third, and then only to the extent that Congress chooses."Philip P. Frickey, ''Congressional Intent, Practical Reasoning, And The Dynamic Nature Of Federal Indian Law'', 78 {{smallcaps|Cal. L. Rev.}} 1137 (1990). Currently the tribes are authorized to operate their own courts, not as a right of tribal sovereignty, but under a federal law.[[Indian Reorganization Act|Indian Reorganization Act of 1934]], Jun. 18, 1934, ch. 576 {{usstat|48|984}}; Box, at 15-16. As of 2007, about half of the federally recognized tribes have tribal courts.Box, at 14. The power of these courts was limited to minor crimes with a maximum punishment of a $5,000 fine and imprisonment of no more than one year[[Indian Civil Rights Act of 1968]], April 11, 1968, {{usstat|82|77}}. until the passage of the [[Tribal Law and Order Act of 2010]]. Under this new act, tribes may sentence offenders for up to three years per offense and a $15,000 fine.[[Tribal Law and Order Act of 2010]], Jul. 29, 2010, {{usstat|124|2258}}. As a result of Crow Dog and ensuing legislation, jurisdiction in Indian country is complex, as shown by the following table:Matthew Handler, ''Tribal Law And Disorder: A Look at a System of Broken Justice in Indian Country and the Steps Needed to Fix It'', {{smallcaps|75 Brook. L. Rev. 261}} (2009). {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Offender !! Victim !! Crime !! Criminal Jurisdiction !! Law !! Authority |- | Indian|| Indian|| Non-major || Tribal|| Tribal|| |- | Indian|| Any || Major || Federal/Tribal concurrent|| Federal/Tribal concurrent|| Major Crimes Act |- | Indian|| Non-Indian|| Non-major || Federal/Tribal concurrent|| State|| General Crimes Act |- | Non-Indian|| Indian|| Any || Federal|| Federal|| General Crimes Act |- | Non-Indian|| Non-Indian|| Any || State|| State|| |} ===Plenary power doctrine=== The court also created the plenary power doctrine, holding that the federal court did not have jurisdiction because Congress had not passed a law giving jurisdiction to the federal courts or taking away the rights of the tribe.Gulig, at 87. ''Crow Dog'' was the last in a line of sovereignty cases that began with ''Cherokee Nation''; the next major case, ''[[United States v. Kagama]]'', (1886),''[[United States v. Kagama]]'', {{ussc|118|375|1886}}. upheld the plenary power of Congress to enact the Major Crimes Act.Gulig, at 87. The plenary power doctrine allowed Congress to enact any law that it wanted to pass, over the opposition of the tribe or tribes affected. Congress subsequently used this power to breach the [[Medicine Lodge Treaty]] with the [[Kiowa people|Kiowa]] by reducing the size of the Kiowa reservation without their consent.{{refn|The United States admitted that they breached the treaty in ''[[Lone Wolf v. Hitchcock]]'' (1903).''[[Lone Wolf v. Hitchcock]]'', {{ussc|187|553|1903}}; Lazarus, at 171.|group="fn"}}{{smallcaps|W. Dale Mason}}, {{smallcaps|Indian Gaming: Tribal Sovereignty and American Politics}} 29 (2000). The use of this power led to complaints of being subject to a lawmaking body without representation, especially prior to being granted U.S. citizenship in 1924.{{refn|Even after becoming U.S. citizens in 1924, many states did not allow Indians to vote, with New Mexico only finally allowing it in 1962.''[http://www.pbs.org/indiancountry/challenges/voting.html Tribal Sovereignty: Voting Rights & Politics]'', in Indian Country Diaries, KERA-PBS, Aug. 29, 2012.|group="fn"}}Jack Blair, ''Demanding a Voice in Our Own Best Interest: A Call for a Delegate of the Cherokee Nation to the United States House of Representatives'', {{smallcaps|20 Am. Indian L. Rev. 225}} (1996). ==See also== * [[Criminal law in the Waite Court]] ==Notes== {{Reflist|group=fn}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikisource}} *''Ex parte Crow Dog'', {{ussc|109|556|1883}}, full text on Justia.com {{featured article}} {{Native American rights}} [[Category:1883 in United States case law]] [[Category:Criminal cases in the Waite Court]] [[Category:Lakota leaders]] [[Category:Native American history of South Dakota]] [[Category:United States Native American case law]] [[Category:United States Supreme Court cases]]
